hange provisions ensure that the potential safety and health
impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or
procedures are considered.
- The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure timely
evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety
standards.
- The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and
instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the
risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.
- Incident Investigation procedures are in place to ensure that corrective measures are
taken, if necessary, following an incident. This ensures that process design, operating
equipment, and operating and maintenance procedures are evaluated to determine
changes needed to prevent recurrence of the incident.
Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the facility include:
- Internal and third-party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection
at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements.
- An ongoing dialogue with the Martin County Local Emergency Planning Committee
(LEPC) will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential
emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops.
All interested citizens or community organizations are encouraged to contact the LEPC for the
latest information on emergency response for the county. The facility coordinates its response
capabilities and personnel with those of the county on an ongoing basis.

by having a continuous flare.
- Providing automated and manual valves to isolate portions of the process.
- Installing hydrocarbon gas detectors throughout the gas plant.
- Installing fire eye detectors throughout the gas plant to alarm personnel of a possible
fire.
- Installing security lighting to facilitate observation of the entire facility.
- Minimizing the possibility of emergencies by manning the facility continuously.
- Providing an evacuation alarm system in order to safely evacuate the facility during
emergency situations.
- Conducting periodic operational rounds to ensure problems are detected and
corrected in a timely manner.

Five-Year Accident History
No incident resulting in onsite injuries, death or significant property damage or known offsite
impacts, such as death, injury, property damage, shelter in place, evacuation, or environmental
damage from a regulated substance has occurred at the facility within the last five years.

Emergency Response Program
The facility will conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any
emergency response actions necessary with the Martin County Local Emergency Planning
Committee. Also involved in emergency response for the facility will be the Martin County Sheriff Department and the Martin County Volunteer Fire Department. The Plant Foreman is responsible for coordinating the emergency actions when an incident occurs within the facility. An emergency response program is in place at the facility and that program has been coordinated with local officials. The emergency response program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program, coupled with the Environmental, Health, and
Safety Management Systems, forms the framework for continuous safety improvement. Some of the key components of the safety program are:
- The Management of C

uct pipelines. The NGL
stream passes through a liquid amine treater to remove carbon dioxide and hydrogen sulfide, if
any, and is pumped into the product sales pipeline for distribution.
The RMP flammable substances and mixtures stored or processed at the facility are the
flammable mixture comprised of methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, butane, isopentane, and pentane, which is being processed through the plant; as well as propane, which is used as
refrigerant in the cryogenic process. There are no toxic substances present at the facility in
amounts greater than threshold quantity.

WTG has determined that MCGP is classified as a Program Level 3 facility under the RMP
regulation because the nearest public receptor is within the worst-case scenario flammable
endpoint radius, and the facility is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard.
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are
part of the high standards striven for by WTG. These high standards include:
- Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations.
- Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are
minimized.
- Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated
with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
- Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.

Prevention Program
The Martin County Gas Plant is operating under a prevention program that involves identifying
and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases. A few examples of the
prevention features implemented at this facility include:
- Providing overpressure relief valves on all pressurized vessels.
- Providing level transmitters and alarms on all vessels to help prevent overfilling.
- Minimizing the possibility of an interruption in the combustion of hydrocarbo

WTG North Permian Midstream LLC
Martin County Gas Plant
Stanton, Texas
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMPlan)
Introduction and Policies

WTG North Permian Midstream LLC (WTG) is committed to managing all operations in a manner
that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors
and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations. WTGs management
philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental, Health, and
Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and
by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.
The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide information about operations at
the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the
event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the facility, and planned changes to improve safety at the facility.

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

WTG owns and operates a natural gas processing plant located near Stanton, Texas. The Martin
County Gas Plant (MCGP) treats and dehydrates natural gas to produce residue gas (methane)
and natural gas liquids (NGL). After processing, the residue gas,  NGL, and condensate exit the plant via product pipelines. 

Pre-treated, sweet inlet natural gas enters the plant via a pipeline and passes through an inlet
scrubber to remove entrained and free-flowing liquids. Following the scrubber, the gas is
compressed and sent through molecular sieve gas dehydration units, which remove any
remaining water. The gas then flows through filters, is cooled using gas-to-gas exchangers, and
enters the cryogenic NGL recovery plant. Propane is used as a refrigerant in this process. Gas
is routed to a demethanizer tower, which separates it into a residual gas product stream and an
NGL product stream. The residue gas then exits the plant via prod
